concern:
I have recently started my Masters and I am having a really hard time working with my PI. 
She’s very controlling, nit picking of everything I do and nothing that I do is ever enough for her.  I have been going above and beyond to do my experiments and also help out at the lab because it’s only me there. No lab technician or other students just me, so I do my experiments plus I also clear out the lab and make sure everything is in order. 
My problem now is that my main experiment has been failing I can’t seem to yield any results, and when I ask her for help she tells me I need to think on my own and when she tries to help she ends up yelling at me and putting me really down. 

I go home everyday after the lab and cry; she’s been really affecting my mental health. 

I have been thinking about reaching out to my co-supervisor to see if I could work in their lab for a while but I’m not sure if I should do this behind her back. Or ever reaching out to my thesis advisory committee but once again idk if I should go behind her back or talk to her about it first. 

If anyone can give me some advice that would be greatly appreciated thank you !!

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you in a safe and non-judgmental space. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or in your heart, and know that your thoughts and feelings are valid.
Thanks for being here, I really appreciate having someone to talk to about this. I’ve just been feeling so overwhelmed with my PI and the lab situation, and it’s been really hard on me mentally.

That sounds really tough, and I can see how it would be overwhelming to deal with both your PI and lab situation at the same time. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been happening with your PI and the lab that's been weighing on you?

Yeah, it’s just been a lot to handle, feeling like I can’t do anything right and being stuck on my own with no real support. I’m constantly stressed about messing up, and it’s just draining me every day.

It sounds like you've been carrying a heavy load with very little support, and that must be incredibly exhausting. How long have you been feeling this way, and have you noticed any patterns in your stress or feelings of inadequacy?

Honestly, it’s been like this pretty much since I started my Masters a few months ago, just building up over time. I feel like every interaction with my PI just makes me doubt myself more, and it’s worse when things in the lab don’t go right.

It seems like this has been an ongoing struggle for you, and it's understandable how the constant pressure and lack of support could contribute to those feelings of self-doubt. What would it be like to imagine a situation where you felt more supported and confident in your abilities, both in your work with your PI and in the lab?

I think it would feel amazing to have that kind of support, like a huge weight off my shoulders. Just picturing someone actually guiding me without judgment or having a team to lean on in the lab would make such a difference.

That's a really powerful image, and it's clear how much of an impact that kind of support could have on your well-being and confidence. What steps do you think would need to happen for you to start moving towards that kind of supportive environment, and what would be the most important things for you to focus on first?

I guess the first step would be to figure out how to get some kind of support, maybe talking to my co-supervisor or someone else who could help without making things worse with my PI. I think the most important thing right now is just finding a way to not feel so alone in this, and maybe getting some advice on how to handle the situation without it blowing up.

It's important to prioritize finding support without exacerbating the situation with your PI. Have you considered discussing this with a trusted colleague or someone in your department who might be able to offer guidance without compromising your relationship with your PI? It might also be helpful to explore ways to build your confidence and resilience in the lab, such as setting small, achievable goals or practicing self-compassion when things don't go as planned.

Yeah, I haven’t really talked to anyone in the department yet because I’m kinda worried it might get back to my PI and make things even messier. I like the idea of setting small goals, though, and trying to be kinder to myself—it’s just hard to know where to start when I’m feeling so beat down.

It's understandable to feel cautious about sharing your concerns within the department, especially if you're worried about repercussions with your PI. Perhaps starting with a small, manageable goal like practicing self-compassion when faced with setbacks could help build your confidence and create a sense of momentum. What would that look like for you in your daily work?

I think it would mean, like, not beating myself up every time an experiment doesn’t work out, maybe just taking a step back and telling myself it’s okay to mess up sometimes. I guess I could try writing down one thing I did well each day, even if it’s small, to kinda shift my focus a bit.

That sounds like a great place to start, and I'm glad you're considering ways to cultivate self-compassion in your daily work. It might be helpful to reflect on how practicing self-compassion could impact your overall well-being and confidence in the lab, and what other small goals or strategies could complement this approach. How do you think this practice might influence your interactions with your PI or your ability to seek support from others?

I think if I can start feeling a bit better about myself, it might help me handle my PI’s criticism without taking it so personally, like I could maybe brush it off a little easier. It could also give me the courage to reach out for support from someone else, like my co-supervisor, without feeling so scared about the fallout.

It's great that you're starting to see how cultivating self-compassion could have a positive impact on your well-being and your interactions with your PI. Building on this idea, what are some other small, achievable goals you could set for yourself in the lab, such as seeking feedback from your co-supervisor or practicing mindfulness techniques to manage stress?

I think setting a goal to have a quick chat with my co-supervisor about a specific part of my project could be doable, just to get some input without making it a big deal. Also, maybe taking a few minutes each day to just breathe and clear my head could help me not feel so overwhelmed all the time.

It's great to see that you're taking steps towards addressing your concerns and improving your situation in the lab. Remember, small, manageable goals can make a big difference over time. To summarize, your action steps are to:
- Practice self-compassion by reframing negative self-talk and acknowledging your strengths.
- Reach out to your co-supervisor for feedback and support.
- Practice mindfulness techniques, such as deep breathing exercises, to manage stress and feel more centered.
Remember, these are just a few strategies to help you get started, and it's important to be patient with yourself as you work through this process. You deserve to feel supported and valued in your work, and it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Keep in mind that you can always come back to these strategies and build on them as you continue to grow and develop in your role.

Thanks for laying that out—it feels good to have a clear plan to start with. I’m a bit nervous about putting these into action, but I’ll give it a shot and see how it goes. So, before we wrap up, do you have any quick tips on how to stay consistent with these steps when things get hectic in the lab?

client: I think it would feel amazing to have that kind of support, like a huge weight off my shoulders. Just picturing someone actually guiding me without judgment or having a team to lean on in the lab would make such a difference.

I think the most important thing right now is just finding a way to not feel so alone in this, and maybe getting some advice on how to handle the situation without it blowing up.

Have you considered discussing this with a trusted colleague or someone in your department who might be able to offer guidance without compromising your relationship with your PI? client: I think if I can start feeling a bit better about myself, it might help me handle my PI’s criticism without taking it so personally, like I could maybe brush it off a little easier. It could also give me the courage to reach out for support from someone else, like my co-supervisor, without feeling so scared about the fallout.

Building on this idea, what are some other small, achievable goals you could set for yourself in the lab, such as seeking feedback from your co-supervisor or practicing mindfulness techniques to manage stress?

Also, maybe taking a few minutes each day to just breathe and clear my head could help me not feel so overwhelmed all the time.
therapist: It's great to see that you're taking steps towards addressing your concerns and improving your situation in the lab. Remember, small, manageable goals can make a big difference over time. To summarize, your action steps are to:
- Practice self-compassion by reframing negative self-talk and acknowledging your strengths.

Remember, these are just a few strategies to help you get started, and it's important to be patient with yourself as you work through this process. You deserve to feel supported and valued in your work, and it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Keep in mind that you can always come back to these strategies and build on them as you continue to grow and develop in your role.
